title: 107_hr5596
content:
Exemption for certain state and local political committees from notification and reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments allow political committees of state or local candidates and state or local committees of political parties to be exempt from notification and reporting requirements. Effective date aligns with previous amendments. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exempt qualified State or local political organizations from certain notification and reporting requirements. The term 'qualified State or local political organization' refers to a political organization whose exempt functions are solely for influencing or attempting to influence. The curr_chunk discusses the influence on the selection of individuals for public office or political organizations, subject to state reporting laws. The curr_chunk requires disclosure of expenditure and contribution details, as well as information on the individuals involved. The curr_chunk specifies that organizations must report certain information publicly and make it available for inspection. State law differences are disregarded if they do not significantly impact reporting requirements. The State law does not require organizations to identify certain details. The State law does not require organizations to disclose details such as the employer and occupation of contributors, recipients of expenditures, purpose of expenditures, and dates of contributions and expenditures. De minimis errors in complying with State reporting and public inspection requirements will not disqualify an organization as a qualified State or local political organization, as long as errors are corrected promptly. The term 'qualified State or local political organization' excludes organizations where a federal candidate or office holder controls or significantly participates in the organization's direction. The amendments made by this section regarding the direction, solicitation of contributions, and disbursements by the organization will take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. SEC. 3. EXEMPTION FROM ANNUAL RETURN REQUIREMENTS. Income Tax Returns Required Only for Political Organization. Amendment made to section 6012(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Income Tax Returns Not Subject to Disclosure. Amendments made to sections 6104(b) and 6104(d) of the Code regarding disclosure and public inspection of annual returns. Amendment made to section 6033 of the Internal Revenue Code regarding information returns required by political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more. Annual returns must be filed by political organizations meeting the specified criteria. The Internal Revenue Code requires political organizations exempt from taxation under section 501(a) to file annual returns with necessary information for carrying out section 527. Certain organizations are exempt from filing, such as State or local political party committees, caucuses, and authorized committees of candidates for Federal office. The Internal Revenue Code mandates that certain political organizations exempt from taxation under section 501(a) must file annual returns with required information for section 527 compliance. Exceptions to filing include State or local political party committees, caucuses, and authorized committees of candidates for Federal office. Additionally, the Secretary has the discretion to waive the filing requirement if deemed unnecessary for efficient tax administration. The amendments made by this section to the internal revenue laws will take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. SEC. 4. NOTIFICATION OF INTERACTION OF REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Federal Election Commission, shall publicize the effect of the amendments made by this Act and the interaction of requirements to file a notification or report under section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and reports under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Information provided shall be included in any appropriate form, instruction, notice, or other guidance issued to the public regarding reporting requirements of political organizations or reporting requirements under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. SEC. 5. WAIVER OF FILING AMOUNTS. SEC. 5. WAIVER OF FILING AMOUNTS. The Secretary may waive tax assessed on an organization for failure to comply with requirements under subsection (i) or amount imposed for failure to comply with subsection (j) if failure was due to reasonable cause. Effective after June 30, 2000. (a) Unsegregated Funds Not To Avoid Tax.--Paragraph (4) of section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include exempt function income whether or not segregated for use for an exempt function.
(b) Procedures for Assessment and Collection of Amounts.--Paragraph (1) of section 527(j) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to state that the amount imposed shall be assessed and collected in the same manner as penalties imposed by section 6652(c).
(c) Duplicate Written Filings Not Required.--Subparagraph (A) of section 527(i)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended. Section 527(i)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow electronic filing. Section 7207 is amended to include fraudulent returns under different sections. Section 527(j)(3) is amended to include additional information in reports and allow for electronic filing. The amendment allows for electronic filing of reports under Section 527(j)(7) if contributions or expenditures exceed $50,000 in a calendar year. Additionally, the Secretary is required to make these reports available for public inspection on the Internet. The Secretary must make reports filed under Section 527(j)(7) available for public inspection on the Internet within 48 hours. The database must be searchable by various items such as names, states, contributors, recipients of expenditures, and time periods. The database of reports filed under Section 527(j)(7) must be downloadable and searchable by various items. Amendments include specifying time periods of notices, contents of notice, and timing of notice in case of material change. Amendments to Section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 require notice of any material changes within 30 days. Failure to provide notice of a material change will result in adjustments to income and deductions for the period of the change. Effective Dates for the amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) apply to failures after the enactment of the Act. Subsection (c) amendments take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. Subsection (d) applies to reports and notices after the Act's enactment. Subsections (e)(1) and (f) apply to filings more than 30 days after the Act. Subsections (e)(2) and (e)(3) apply to required reports. The amendments made by subsection (g) apply to material changes after the enactment of this Act. A transition rule allows for a 30-day period for filing a notice under section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code for material changes occurring within that timeframe. The amendments made by this Act affect existing disclosures filed with the Secretary of the Treasury, which will continue to be subject to disclosure provisions under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
